newsitem.title: INDIA: India SEBI panel for curbs, not ban, on short sales.
newsitem.headline: India SEBI panel for curbs, not ban, on short sales.

text.p: A panel set up by the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) said on Friday it proposed to tighten regulatory control over short sales to curb excessive bear hammering in a depressed market.

"Regulating short sales may not necessarily lead to an immediate recovery in share prices," SEBI said in a statement. "However, the present amplification of this bearish trend ... calls for a tightening of the conditions for short sales."
The panel ruled out banning short sales.

"The committee is of the firm view that in as much as short sales provide liquidity and competitive prices in the stock markets," the panel said, "there is no case for putting a blanket bank on the short sales."

The committee recommended the imposition of 15 percent "differential" deposit margins by brokers on short sale positions in 15 volatile stocks. These margins will be 15 percentage points higher than on long positions, the SEBI statement said.
The 15 volatile stocks are: State Bank of India, ITC, Reliance, TISCO, MTNL, L&T, TELCO, BSES, Bajaj Auto, ACC, Gujarat Ambuja Cement,IPCL, Tata Power, Hind Lever and Oriental Bank.
The committee also asked stock exchanges to demand more transparency from brokers in another 45 volatile shares.
SEBI said the margin will be in addition to the mark-to-market margin already collected by exchanges.
The 13-member SEBI committee set up on November 22 was headed by B.D. Shah, former managing director of state-run General Insurance Corporation.
